docs.lead_paragraph: Public health officials are now encouraging women to make sure they are in optimal health well in advance of a pregnancy.

headline.main: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late
headline.print_headline: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, women have had it drummed into them that prenatal care is the key to having a healthy baby, and that they should see a doctor as soon as they know they are pregnant. But by then, it may already be too late. Public health officials are now encouraging women to make sure they are in optimal health well in advance of a pregnancy to reduce the risk of preventable birth defects and complications. They have recast the message to emphasize not only prenatal care, as they did in the past, but also what they are calling ''preconception care.''

headline.main: That Prenatal Visit May Be Months Too Late

docs.abstract: Many medical experts say that prepregnancy efforts are critical in having healthy baby; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends 10 specific measures along with prepregnancy checkups for women who may become pregnant; some say that women should maintain suggested prepregnancy health standards throughout reproductive years; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tall wood tables line the parking lot of St. John's Roman Catholic Church on McCarter Highway. Volunteers slowly unload a truck full of 4,000 frozen portions of chicken Parmesan from a New York restaurant. Seagulls are bickering overhead, edging out pigeons to land on bread crusts. Hundreds of people form a line along the spike-topped fence.

headline.main: At a Newark Church, Hot Meals, Lost Dreams and Hopes for Tomorrow

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans who were expecting a more moderate administration in the wake of this month’s elections will be shocked by the appointment of Eric Keroack to head family planning programs at the Department of Health and Human Services.

docs.lead_paragraph: P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street Long Island City, Queens Through Jan. 8 This retrospective of John Latham, a British octogenarian who died earlier this year, suggests a series of nesting time capsules. It spans nearly 50 years and Mr. Latham's work, concerned with time, preservation and decay, often seems like a repository for mid-20th-century ideas.

headline.main: John Latham -- Time Base and the Universe

docs.lead_paragraph: A device that measures a baby’s blood oxygen during labor has failed to meet doctors’ hopes that it would lead to fewer Caesarean sections and safer deliveries, a new study has concluded.

headline.main: Oxygen Monitor Fails to Help Doctors Detect Birth Risks
headline.print_headline: Oxygen Monitor Fails to Help Doctors Detect Birth Risks
